children: A patient with right lower extremity swelling is evaluated for possible deep venous thrombosis (DVT). Ultrasonography is performed with the probe just below the inguinal ligament in the transverse plane.
(Note that there is no sound for this
Which of the following is seen in this study?

The patient's ultrasound shows normal compression of the common femoral vein. Normally, in the absence of a clot, the anterior and posterior walls of the vein will touch when gentle pressure with the probe is applied, as demonstrated here. On the left side of the
) can be seen pulsating just at the level of bifurcation, and the position of the greater saphenous vein (

) on the right indicates that the collapsing structure is the common femoral vein. Normal compression suggests patency of the femoral vein and the absence of deep venous thrombosis (DVT). Compared with formal venous ultrasonography, which examines the entire lower extremity venous system, a point-of-care study for DVT typically images three sites: the common femoral vein (

); the junction of the common femoral, femoral, and deep femoral veins; and the popliteal vein at the level of the knee. Results of a point-of-care study for DVT should be considered indeterminate if the intended vessels are not visualized or the anatomy is not recognizable.

objective.__html: Evaluate for deep venous thrombosis using point-of-care ultrasonography.
